arm_group.description: Patients will receive an extra MRI scan in addition to their routine scan.

brief_summary.textblock:
This study will look at the feasibility of using a type of Magnetic Resonance Imaging
      called Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI) to detect your implanted radioactive seeds.
      Researchers hope that using SWI will eliminate the need to use CT imaging to detect your
      implanted radioactive seeds.

      This study will also see if the MRI seed detection is as effective as current standard
      practice of seed detection (routine MRI and CT imaging). This technique would be beneficial
      for brachytherapy without the need to fuse the MRI and CT images, as is done currently.

clinical_study.brief_title: Identifying Prostate Brachytherapy Seeds Using MRI
clinical_study.condition: Prostate Cancer Patients Who Have Brachytherapy Seed Implant

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. At least 18 years old

          2. Histologic diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate

          3. No contraindications for Pelvic body MRI

          4. Patients undergoing LDR brachytherapy at PMH and scheduled for post implant analysis
             with CT-MR (standard at PMH)

          5. Ability to provide written informed consent to participate in the study

        Exclusion Criteria:

          1. Contraindication for Pelvic body MRI

          2. Patient not willing/consenting for this study

intervention.description: Patient will receive an additional MRI scan in addition to their standard of care imaging

facility.name: University Health Network, The Princess Margaret

clinical_study.official_title: Identifying Prostate Brachytherapy Seeds Using MRI

other_outcome.measure: Compare the prostate dosimetry (V100 and D90) in prostate low dose rate therapy using MR alone with CT/MR fusion.

overall_official.affiliation: University Health Network, The Princess Margaret

primary_outcome.measure: Determine if using the MR scan -(SWI) used to detect the implanted radioactive seeds will reduce registration errors
Determine if using the MR scan -(SWI) used to detect the implanted radioactive seeds will reduce planning time for the post-implant plan
Determine if using the MR scan  -(SWI) used to detect the implanted radioactive seeds will eliminate the CT scan of the patient.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Our goal is to perfectly match these two modalities with acceptance test of 97%. This technique would be beneficial for LDR (Low Dose Rate) Brachytherapy without need to fuse the CT and MR images and eliminate any image registration uncertainly.
secondary_outcome.measure: Compare the differences in MR seed identification using the MR pulse sequence vs. CT images.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Diagnostic
